raw_text:
Labour seeks to quell feud talk
 
 Labour's leadership put on a show of unity at a campaign poster launch after MPs criticised Tony Blair and Gordon Brown over reports of their rift.
 
 Mr Brown was joined at the launch by John Prescott and Alan Milburn, the man controversially put in charge of election planning by Mr Blair. A private meeting on Monday saw normally loyal MPs warn that feuding could jeopardise their election hopes. It follows a new book charting disputes between prime minister and chancellor.
 
 The event was the first time Mr Milburn has shared a platform with the chancellor since taking Mr Brown's traditional poll planning role. But the pair chatted amicably and Mr Brown insisted he was happy with his current campaign task. Asked about how he would deal with claims that he did not trust the prime minister, Mr Brown replied: "You can see that our record on the economy is about the British people trusting us to run the economy."
 
 He refused to comment on the new book, saying nobody should be distracted from the business of government. Mr Brown later told reporters: "Of course I trust the prime minister." Downing Street cited that comment when reporters' suggested Mr Brown had pointedly failed to deny claims he had once told Mr Blair: "There is nothing you could ever say to me now that I could ever believe". Labour's new posters say Britain is enjoying the lowest inflation since the 1960s, lowest unemployment for 29 years and the lowest mortgage rates for 40 years. They urge voters not to let the Tories take things backwards. Mr Milburn promised a poll campaign "which is upbeat, confident and above all else optimistic about the future of our country".
 
 Conservative co-chairman Liam Fox derided the photo call, saying: "The show of unity was the worst acting I have seen since Prisoner Cell Block H." Labour had broken promises by raising taxes 66 times and brought the slowest economic growth in the English-speaking world, he said.
 
 The prime minister and chancellor faced backbench discontent at Monday's meeting of the Parliamentary Labour Party over claims made in journalist Robert Peston's new book. Mr Blair told MPs and peers: "I know from everyone here, in Cabinet and government, nothing is going to get in the way of a unified Labour Party with a unified position and winning the third term people desperately need." Labour's Paul Flynn said the pair had had a "scorching" from MPs.
 
 On Tuesday, deputy prime minister Mr Prescott told BBC News: "They told us very clearly, it was the troops telling the leaders: get in line." The new book claims Mr Prescott hosted a dinner in November 2003 where the prime minister told Mr Brown he would stand down before the next election because he had lost trust over the Iraq war. Mr Blair then changed his mind in June 2004, after Cabinet allies intervened and amid suspicion the chancellor was manoeuvring against him, writes Mr Peston. Mr Prescott said there was a dinner but the discussions were confidential. "Of course as a waiter for 10 years I have a professional ability here," he joked.
llama3.2:1b:
Labour's leadership launched campaign posters after MPs criticized Tony Blair and Gordon Brown over reports of their rift. 

MPs warned that feuding could jeopardize election hopes due to disputes between the two.

The Labour Party was joined by John Prescott and Alan Milburn at a campaign launch, marking Mr Brown's first public appearance since taking charge of election planning from Mr Blair.

Mr Brown denied claims he did not trust Mr Blair, saying "You can see that our record on the economy is about the British people trusting us to run the economy".

Labour posters highlight low inflation, unemployment, and mortgage rates as reasons for optimism. 

The Conservative Party criticized the photo call as a lack of unity, with Liam Fox calling it the worst acting since Prisoner Cell Block H.

MPs were also critical of Labour's past actions, including raising taxes 66 times and slow economic growth.
llama3.2:3b: Labour's leadership showed unity at a campaign poster launch after MPs criticized Tony Blair and Gordon Brown over reports of their rift. Mr Brown denied claims he didn't trust the prime minister, saying his record on the economy proves their trust. Conservative Liam Fox mocked the photo call, calling it the worst acting since Prisoner Cell Block H.
gemma2:2b: Labour leadership attempted to quell media speculation about Tony Blair and Gordon Brown's feud.  MPs held private meetings expressing concern over potential political damage from their public disagreements, and Labour campaign team launched posters emphasizing economic successes. Conservative Party leader countered with criticism of Labour's record and a perceived lack of unity.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Labour supporters expressed relief at MPs' criticism of Blair and Brown over their rift in a campaign poster launch, while Labour leader Tony Blair acknowledged his current role was 'above all else' optimistic about the future of the country.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Labour's Tony Blair and Gordon Brown met to quell criticism over feuding with John Prescott and Alan Milburn, who had previously been criticized for taking on campaign planning duties traditionally held by Mr Blair. Despite the meeting, Labour's new posters highlight improved economic conditions in Britain compared to previous years. The Conservative Party was critical of the show of unity, while the prime minister assured MPs that unified government was crucial for winning elections.
qwen2.5:3b: Labour's leadership displayed unity by launching campaign posters despite MPs criticizing Tony Blair and Gordon Brown over reports of their rift. A private meeting revealed loyal MPs warned feuding could harm election prospects, leading to a public event where John Prescott joined Gordon Brown and Alan Milburn. Despite allegations in a new book about potential conflicts between the prime minister and chancellor, Brown insisted he was happy with his campaign role and claimed people trusted him on economic issues. Labour posters highlighted low unemployment rates and low inflation since 1960s, urging voters to support them against the Tories. Conservative co-chairman Liam Fox criticized this event as a display of unity, while Deputy Prime Minister Prescott revealed MPs sharply criticized Brown in a private meeting. A new book alleges disputes between Blair and Brown over Iraq war; Prescott maintains these discussions were confidential.
opencoder:1.5b:
Labour seeks to quell feud talk
Labour's leadership put on a show of unity at a campaign poster launch after MPs criticized Tony Blair and Gordon Brown over reports of their rift. Mr Brown was joined at the launch by John Prescott and Alan Milburn, the man controversially put in charge of election planning by Mr Blair. A private meeting on Monday saw normally loyal MPs warn that feuding could jeopardise their election hopes. It follows a new book charting disputes between prime minister and chancellor. The event was the first time Mr Milburn has shared a platform with the chancellor since taking Mr Brown's traditional poll planning role. But the pair chatted amicably and Mr Brown insisted he was happy with his current campaign task. Asked about how he would deal with claims that he did not trust the prime minister, Mr Brown replied: "You can see that our record on the economy is about the British people trusting us to run the economy." He refused to comment on the new book, saying nobody should be distracted from the business of government. Downing Street cited that comment when reporters' suggested Mr Brown had pointedly failed to deny claims he had once told Mr Blair: "There is nothing you could ever say to me now that I could ever believe". Labour's new posters say Britain is enjoying the lowest inflation since the 19th century and lowest unemployment for 29 years and the lowest mortgage rates for 40 years. They urge voters not to let the Tories take things backwards. Mr Milburn promised a poll campaign "which is upbeat, confident and above all else optimistic about the future of our country". 
Conservative co-chairman Liam Fox derided the photo call, saying: "The show of unity was the worst acting I have seen since Prisoner Cell Block H." Labour had broken promises by raising taxes 66 times and brought the slowest economic growth in the English-speaking world. They argued that the Tories needed a strong government and they promised they would stand down before the next election.
On Tuesday, deputy prime minister Mr Prescott told BBC News: "They told us very clearly, it was the troops telling the leaders: get in line." The new book claims Mr Prescott hosted a dinner in November 2003 where the prime minister told Mr Brown he would stand down before the next election because he had lost trust over the Iraq war. Mr Blair then changed his mind in June 2004, after Cabinet allies intervened and amid suspicion the chancellor was manoeuvring against him, writes Mr Peston. Mr Prescott said there was a dinner but the discussions were confidential. "Of course as a waiter for 10 years I have a professional ability here," he joked.

Labour sought to unite forces at a campaign event after criticizing Tony Blair and Gordon Brown over their rift. A private meeting on Monday saw loyal MPs warn about feuding hoping for election hope, reflecting the potential impact of the feud on their chances. The prime minister and Chancellor shared a new book charting disputes between them, urging voters not to let the Tories run the country down. Labour aimed to bring economic growth and stability but faced backbenchers who were critical of their united position, with Blair accusing a former colleague of misleading the public about Blair's stance on Iraq.

The new posters highlighted British economic prosperity—low inflation, unemployment for 29 years, and low mortgage rates for 40 years. Labour promised an optimistic poll campaign focusing on the country's future. Backbenchers organized a dinner debate in 2003, with Mr. Brown accusing a former Polls Polls leader of standing down before election time due to Blair's loss of trust over Iraq. The text also notes that Blair later changed his mind, showing a complex dynamic between the PM and Chancellor.
tinyllama:1.1b: The Labour Party has unveiled their new campaign poster aimed at addressing concerns over the economic situation in the UK, promoting optimism about future prospects under the leadership of Tony Blair and Gordon Brown, and highlighting their commitment to reducing taxes and promoting economic growth. However, the launch of the poster has led to criticism from Conservative MPs who accuse Labour of "panick[ing]" during a "recession" and promoting the idea that they are in the process of "sinking" under Tony Blair's leadership. The new book published by journalist Robert Peaton, however, claims that Labour broke election promises on taxes, economic growth, and slowed economic growth during the first three years of Tony Blair's premiership, before rising above them after 2007.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The Labour party is trying to quell any feud talk by organizing a unity campaign at their poster launch. The campaign features former chancellor Tony Blair, who was the main critic of Prime Minister John Prescott, now leader of the Labour party. They will be promoting policies that will help improve Britain's economic situation and boost job opportunities for people. The main opposition Conservative Party has criticized the Labour party for raising taxes, bringing slow economic growth, and not prioritizing education or health care.
phi:2.7b: The Labour leadership sought to quell rumors of feud between Tony Blair and Gordon Brown by showcasing their unity at a campaign poster launch, with support from John Prescott and Alan Milburn. MPs had expressed concern that the feud could hurt their election chances. Downing Street cited Mr Brown's comment about trusting his prime minister when asked about claims in a new book. Labour's posters highlighted the party's record on the economy and urged voters not to let the Conservatives take things backward. The Conservative co-chairman Liam Fox criticized the photo call, saying it was poorly acted. There were concerns within the Parliamentary Labour Party over claims made in a new book by journalist Robert Peston about tensions between Mr Blair and his allies.
orca-mini:3b: The text discusses a controversy within the Labour Party regarding reports of a rift between the prime minister and chancellor. Mr Brown was joined at a campaign poster launch by John Prescott and Alan Milburn, who was controversially put in charge of election planning by Mr Blair. The event marked the first time Mr Milburn had shared a platform with the chancellor since taking Mr Brown's traditional poll planning role. However, the pair chatted amicably and Mr Brown insisted he was happy with his current campaign task. When asked about claims that he did not trust the prime minister, Mr Brown replied: "You can see that our record on the economy is about the British people trusting us to run the economy." He refused to comment on the new book, saying nobody should be distracted from the business of government. Mr Brown later told reporters: "Of course I trust the prime minister." Labour's new posters say Britain is enjoying the lowest inflation since the 1960s, lowest unemployment for 29 years and the lowest mortgage rates for 40 years. They urge voters not to let the Tories take things backwards. However, Conservative co-chairman Liam Fox derided the photo call, saying: "The show of unity was the worst acting I have seen since Prisoner Cell Block H." The prime minister and chancellor faced backbench discontent at Monday's meeting of the Parliamentary Labour Party over claims made in journalist Robert Peston's new book. Mr Blair told MPs and peers: "I know from everyone here, in Cabinet and government, nothing is going to get in the way of a unified Labour Party with a unified position and winning the third term people desperately need."
hermes3:3b: Labour tries to show unity after MPs criticised Tony Blair and Gordon Brown over alleged feud in campaign poster launch following reports of rift between them.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Labour leadership attempted to display unity following reports of a rift between Tony Blair and Gordon Brown, with both attending a campaign poster launch. This event marked the first time Alan Milburn shared a platform with Brown since taking over his poll planning role. Labour's new posters emphasized their economic achievements, such as low inflation and low mortgage rates. However, Conservative co-chairman Liam Fox criticized the event, accusing the party of breaking promises and experiencing the slowest economic growth in the English-speaking world.

Brown appeared alongside John Prescott and Alan Milburn, who had controversially taken over Brown's election planning role. Despite past tensions, Brown and Milburn interacted amicably, with Brown affirming his trust in Blair and refusing to comment on a new book detailing their disputes. Labour's new campaign posters highlighted economic achievements, while Milburn promised an optimistic campaign. Conservative co-chairman Liam Fox mocked the unity display, accusing Labour of breaking promises and overseeing slow economic growth. At a private meeting, backbench MPs warned that internal feuding could harm election prospects. Blair reassured MPs of Labour's unity, while Prescott acknowledged MPs had urged leaders to align. The book claims Blair once promised to step down but later changed his mind, with Prescott confirming a related dinner but keeping details confidential.
stablelm2:1.6b: Labour's leadership hosted a unity event following MPs' criticism of Tony Blair and Gordon Brown over reports of a rift, while Alan Milburn shares a platform with the chancellor for the first time since taking Brown's poll planning role. The Labour party urges voters not to let the Tories take their achievements forward in an upbeat campaign. However BCC chairman Liam Fox criticized the photo call as the worst acting he has ever seen. granite3.1-dense:2b: At a campaign poster launch, Labour's leadership attempted to project unity after MPs expressed concerns about a potential rift between then-Chancellor Gordon Brown and former Prime Minister Tony Blair. The event featured Brown alongside John Prescott and Alan Milburn, who had previously been in charge of election planning by Blair. This meeting followed the publication of a book detailing disputes between the two prime ministers. Despite the feuding allegations, Brown and Milburn appeared amicable during the event. Brown refused to comment on the book's claims but emphasized Labour's economic achievements. Conservative co-chairman Liam Fox criticized the display of unity as poor acting. The MPs' concerns centered around the slow economic growth and broken promises by Labour, which included tax increases and the slowest growth rate in the English-speaking world. The new book reportedly claims Blair initially intended to step down due to trust issues over the Iraq war but changed his mind after Cabinet allies intervened. Prescott maintained that the dinner discussions were confidential.
reference: The new book claims Mr Prescott hosted a dinner in November 2003 where the prime minister told Mr Brown he would stand down before the next election because he had lost trust over the Iraq war.Mr Brown later told reporters: "Of course I trust the prime minister."Mr Brown was joined at the launch by John Prescott and Alan Milburn, the man controversially put in charge of election planning by Mr Blair.Downing Street cited that comment when reporters' suggested Mr Brown had pointedly failed to deny claims he had once told Mr Blair: "There is nothing you could ever say to me now that I could ever believe".The event was the first time Mr Milburn has shared a platform with the chancellor since taking Mr Brown's traditional poll planning role.Mr Blair then changed his mind in June 2004, after Cabinet allies intervened and amid suspicion the chancellor was manoeuvring against him, writes Mr Peston.Mr Prescott said there was a dinner but the discussions were confidential.On Tuesday, deputy prime minister Mr Prescott told BBC News: "They told us very clearly, it was the troops telling the leaders: get in line."But the pair chatted amicably and Mr Brown insisted he was happy with his current campaign task.
